Description: A grotesque male head, broken from a terracotta figure, perhaps a priest, with close-cropped hair, or possibly bald. The front of the head was pressed into a one-piece mould, leaving a mould mark, the back added by hand; the object is solid. Brown Nile silt with dark grey core and sparse fine mica and white (limestone and shell) inclusions. Traces of an overall white dressing and pink paint around the mouth.
Curator's comments: Ptolemaic, third or second century BC (Bailey 2008, 151, pl. 106). Comparanda, include similar examples dated third to second century BC (Török 1995, no. 241) and from a third century BC context at Athribis (Szymańska and Babraj 2004, 35, fig. 7) Szymańska, H. & Babraj, K. 2004. 'Aus den Brennöfen von Athribis (Ägypten): Neue Funde aus dem Ptolemäischen Stadtviertel'. Antike Welt 35.2, 33-7. Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt. Rome.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3575)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.531) (Phase 1)
